headline: Tariffs linger over earnings, even as companies get used to them
summary: STORY: Many U.S. companies have sought to reassure investors that U.S. President Donald Trump's tariffs are "manageable."But corporate America so far this earnings season is signaling that profit margins could be squeezed as consumers push back on higher prices.Bellwethers including Procter & Gamble and 3M have flagged these challenges.And Andy Jassy, CEO of Amazon, told CNBC on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos that the retail giant was seeing prices tick up on its e-commerce platform as sellers have sold the inventory they built up before tariffs went into effect.Numerous companies with global footprints report results in the coming week, including General Motors and Caterpillar.While broader consumer spending has held up, buyers have been more judicious, often looking for value items, particularly lower- and middle-income earners.One economic strategist told Reuters quote, “Most consumers are still mad about the level of current prices and won't take kindly to further hikes.”Levi Strauss reports holiday-quarter results on Wednesday.The company said in October that tariffs would cut its margins more than it had anticipated.  Levis has raised some prices while trying to diversify its supply chain, and the company also warned of a softer consumer environment.Three Harvard University professors have been tracking the price of roughly 360,000 goods, from carpets to coffee, at major online and brick-and-mortar retailers in the United States.They estimate that as of year-end, domestic goods cost about 4.3 percentage points more than would have been expected based on the pre-tariff regime, while imported goods are about 5.8 percentage points more expensive.According to the Yale Budget Lab, the effective tariff rate on U.S. consumers as of mid-November was 14.4%, the highest in 85 years.The current tariff regime could be interrupted if the U.S. Supreme Court rules against President Donald Trump's use of emergency economic powers to implement them.That could lead to massive refunds for companies that had to pay duties.But the process could play out over years, and the White House plans to use other means to keep the tariffs in place.

that profit margins could be squeezed as consumers push back on higher prices.Bellwethers including Procter & Gamble and 3M have flagged these challenges.And Andy Jassy, CEO of Amazon, told CNBC on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum in Davos that the retail giant was seeing prices tick up on its e-commerce platform as sellers have sold the inventory they built up before tariffs went into effect.Numerous companies with global footprints report results in the coming week, including General Motors and Caterpillar.While broader consumer spending has held up, buyers have been more judicious, often looking for value items, particularly lower- and middle-income earners.One economic strategist told Reuters quote, “Most consumers are still mad about the level of current prices and won't take kindly to further hikes.”Levi Strauss reports holiday-quarter results on Wednesday.The company said in October that tariffs would cut its margins more than it had anticipated.  Levis has raised some prices while trying to diversify its supply chain, and the company also warned of a softer consumer environment.Three Harvard University professors have been tracking the price of roughly 360,000 goods, from carpets to coffee, at major online and brick-and-mortar retailers in the United States.They estimate that as of year-end, domestic goods cost about 4.3 percentage points more than would have been expected based on the pre-tariff regime, while imported goods are about 5.8 percentage points more expensive.According to the Yale Budget Lab, the effective tariff rate on U.S. consumers as of mid-November was 14.4%, the highest in 85 years.The current tariff regime could be interrupted if the U.S. Supreme Court rules against President Donald Trump's use of emergency economic powers to implement them.That could lead to massive refunds for companies that had to pay duties.But the process could play out over years, and the White House plans to use other means to keep the tariffs in place.

headline: GCC Construction Equipment Industry Research Report 2025-2030: LNG Expansion, Infrastructure Megaprojects, and Renewable Energy Investments Fuel Demand
summary: The GCC Construction Equipment Market, sized at 68,499 units in 2024, is projected to reach 94,499 units by 2030, with a CAGR of 5.51%. Driven by ambitious urban growth plans like UAE's 2040 Urban Master Plan and Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030, demand for construction equipment, especially earthmoving machinery, is soaring. Major investments in public infrastructure, LNG projects, and renewable energy are fueling market expansion across the GCC. Key players include Caterpillar, Komatsu, and Volvo CE

headline: Option Volatility And Earnings Report For January 26 - 30
summary: It’s the biggest week of the quarter for earnings this week with plenty of big names set to report. This week we have Tesla, Microsoft, Apple, Meta Platforms, UnitedHealth Group, Exxon Mobil, Visa, Mastercard, Chevron and Caterpillar all reporting in what shapes as a busy and pivotal week for stocks.

headline: Stocks Set for Muted Open After Trump’s Tariff Threats, Big Tech Earnings and Fed Meeting in Focus
summary: March S&P 500 E-Mini futures (ESH26) are down -0.05%, and March Nasdaq 100 E-Mini futures (NQH26) are down -0.14% this morning, pointing to a muted open on Wall Street as President Trump’s tariff threats against Canada and the looming risk of a partial U.S. government shutdown curbed risk appetite at the start of a busy week.

headline: Mike Santoli: Can an old bull learn new tricks?
summary: Now in its fourth year, the bull market is maturing and finding it harder to rely on the energy sources of its youth.

headline: 2 High-Flying Stocks to Target This Week and 1 That Underwhelm
summary: Expensive stocks often command premium valuations because the market thinks their business models are exceptional. However, the downside is that high expectations are already baked into their prices, leaving little room for error if they stumble even slightly.

raw.headline: 2 High-Flying Stocks to Target This Week and 1 That Underwhelm
raw.summary: Expensive stocks often command premium valuations because the market thinks their business models are exceptional. However, the downside is that high expectations are already baked into their prices, leaving little room for error if they stumble even slightly.
